items.title: Deep Sleep in Tanygrisiau, Wales
items.excerpt: Nestled within the rugged landscape of Snowdonia National Park, Deep Sleep offers thrill-seekers and adventurers a unique opportunity: spending the night in one of the deepest hotel rooms on Earth. This remarkable experience takes place 1,375 feet (419 meters) underground in a…

items.title: Alcazaba in Málaga, Spain
items.excerpt: "Alcazaba" is the Spanish rendering of "the citadel" in Arabic, which is why Málaga's Alcazaba is one of many in Spain. Like most, the monumental structure in Málaga is the product of many centuries of addition, modification, embellishment, and destruction.

items.title: This women’s hub in Kenya is prioritizing joy, culture and financial independence
items.excerpt: The Titeeyio hub was made possible, in part, through a 2024 Impact Grant from The Intrepid Foundation. This grant enabled Paatinai Osim to train more than 20 women and establish the Osim shop—now a stop on many Intrepid Travel Kenya itineraries .

items.title: The Little Red Schoolhouse of Two Harbors in Two Harbors, California
items.excerpt: Tucked away in the quiet village of Two Harbors, this one-room schoolhouse once provided a rare educational outpost on Catalina Island’s rugged western end. It served generations of children whose families worked in the island’s conservation, marine science, and tourism indust…

items.title: Is this pocket-sized Fuji the perfect travel camera, or an overpriced gimmick?
items.excerpt: I love Fuji cameras. I know that’s a terribly compromising thing to admit before reviewing a Fuji camera, but I reckon transparency is more important than feigning neutrality. Besides, I don’t love all Fuji cameras, just the ones I own: The X-Pro 3 and the X100F.

items.title: Franklin Cider Mill  in Bloomfield Hills, Michigan
items.excerpt: The Franklin Cider Mill is an essential autumn pilgrimage for anyone passing through the Detroit suburbs.

items.title: The Palmer House Hotel in Sauk Centre, Minnesota
items.excerpt: The Palmer House Hotel could best be described as a haunted time machine. Built in 1901 by Ralph and Christena Palmer, this establishment and its restaurant/pub have been welcoming guests for well over a century.

items.title: Beyond the Beaten Path: Spain’s Hidden Villages and Untamed Landscapes
Would you take the train to your vacation if your boss gave you more time off?
items.excerpt: These companies are giving their employees extra paid time off if they forego flights in favor of travel by land or sea. Would you do it?

items.title: Channel your inner paleontologist in Alberta, Canada, home to the world’s greatest concentration of dinosaur fossils
items.excerpt: In the vast Dinosaur Hall, which houses more than 30 mounted dinosaur skeletons, I spot the Albertasaurus as well as Pachyrhinosaurus, a herbivorous species that features in episode five, ‘The Journey North’ of Walking with Dinosaurs . That particular Pachyrhinosaurus, along w…

items.title: For Leah Thomas, there is no activism without craft club, self-care and community
items.excerpt: What does crafting and climate advocacy have in common? We spend a day with leading Los Angeles-based environmentalist Leah Thomas to find out.

items.title: A 10 Day Itinerary Down Sweden’s Coast
items.excerpt: There’s nothing like Sweden in the summer. Light hangs in the air for hours, boats nose through island-studded bays, and cafés spill onto sidewalks as Swedes take advantage of the fleeting warm weather.

items.title: The Last Limburger Cheese Plant in America
items.excerpt: Johanna Mayer: A few weeks ago, I called my dad. I had a few questions for him. The topic is Limburger cheese.

items.title: Surf’s up in Taghazout: How this Moroccan surf town stays true to its roots
items.excerpt: Morocco’s coolest surf town is no longer a secret – but as its popularity booms, the local community is rolling with the tides.

items.title: Set-jetting: 10 film and TV locations worth travelling for
items.excerpt: Set-jetting isn’t just a clever play on words. It’s a very real phenomenon.

items.title: After long Covid, I thought I’d never travel again. Luckily, my legs proved me wrong
items.excerpt: Intrepid traveller Carla isn’t one to shy away from a challenge. But after years of dealing with the fatigue and weakness that comes with long Covid, she didn’t need another achievement ticked off the list. She just wanted to feel like herself again.
